thread.title: Deradicalisation Scheme: Eight Referred Daily

author: news.sky
title: Deradicalisation Scheme: Eight Referred Daily
text:
Eight people are being reported to the Government's deradicalisation scheme each day amid concerns authorities are seeing a growing number of potential extremists. Between June and August this year, some 796 people were reported to the Channel programme for possible intervention.
More than 300 people aged under 18 were among those referred to the programme.
New legal measures have been implemented which require public bodies - including schools and councils - to stop people from being radicalised.
There were 349 referrals in July, when the law came into force. The figure represented an increase on the previous month, when there were 327 referrals.
Play video "Feb: Pupils Challenge Extremism" Video: Feb: Pupils Challenge Extremism The number fell to 120 in August when schools were broken up for the summer, according to the data provided by the National Police Chiefs' Council.
The statistics reveal that authorities are identifying a growing number of potential extremists.
There were more referrals to the Channel programme between June and August than for the whole of 2012/13, when the scheme was rolled out in England and Wales.
The Channel programme aims to counter all forms of terrorism, including far-right extremism.
Haras Rafiq, managing director at security think tank Quilliam, said: "The lure of extremism has increased over the last year both from an Islamist and far-right perspective."
Play video "Feb: Boris On 'Jihadi Nonsense'" Video: Feb: Boris On 'Jihadi Nonsense' "There is a symbiotic relationship between the two. More effort needs to come from civil society so that we build resilience in our communities so that these numbers come down."
Security Minister John Hayes said: "As a country, we have a duty to challenge, at every turn, the twisted narrative that has corrupted some of our vulnerable young people.
"Since Channel was rolled out nationally in April 2012, there have been over 4,000 referrals and hundreds of people at risk of being drawn into terrorism have been provided with support.
"Referrals to Channel have increased, but only a small percentage of these go on to require specialist intervention support.
"We have dedicated sufficient resources to the programme to cope with demand and we will keep this position under close review."
